title: CTRL0000055540 - Transcribed Interview of Daniel Herendeen, (March 16, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Zoom, commencing at 2:02 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is a transcribed interview of Daniel
Herendeen conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th
Attack on the United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and spell you last
So this is a staff-led interview.
I don't see any members on the call, but they may
hop in and choose to ask questions, if they do so.
And with me in the room is
So, at this time, could counsel please state your name for the record?
I'm a Federal community defender in
There is an official reporter transcribing the record of this interview.
until each question is completed before you begin your response, and we will try to wait
until your response is complete before we ask our next question.
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses such as shaking your head,
so it is important that you answer each question with an audible verbal response.
I ever see, you know, you nodding yes or shaking no, I'll just mention it for the record and
we can confirm and move on.
We ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
the question is not clear, which very much is possible, please ask for clarification.
do not know the answer, please simply say so.
And then I'm going to go through a couple of, like, important points.
important that you understand that this interview is voluntary.
If at any time you would
like to stop speaking with us, that is your choice.
discuss something with your attorney in private, please let us know and we'll take a break
so you and Ms. Fitzharris can have that conversation.
Second, this interview is not under oath.
Similarly, if at any point you need to
But because this is a formal
congressional investigation, you are obligated under Federal law to tell the truth, the
same as if you were speaking with the FBI or the Department of Justice.
deliberately provide false information to Congress.
information could result in criminal penalties for false statements.
Third, you are not obligated to keep the fact of this interview and what we discuss
prosecutor or the judge on your case, or you can tell no one at all.
You are free to tell whomever you wish that you met with us, including the
Fourth, the select committee is separate and independent from the Department
the select committee in its investigation.
your criminal case and is not agreeing to submit anything on your behalf to the judge.
Nor can we make any representation whether, if you tell the judge you met with us, that
the judge will be more favorable to you during sentencing.
We have no involvement with the prosecutions.
And DOJ is not a part of
The select committee also is not a party to
Fifth, we have agreed with Ms. Fitzharris not to share the substance of what you
say with the Department of Justice prior to your sentencing.
If you told us about evidence of a crime that we thought law enforcement
was unaware of or if we had reason to believe you lied during this interview, then we
would be obligated to tell DOJ or another appropriate law enforcement agency about
And if you tell the judge that you met with us, please understand that it may
prompt questions from the judge about what you said and whether it is consistent with
your prior statements and acceptance of responsibility.
questions, we may get asked to respond and divulge what you said.
And just to note, logistically, if you need a break or you would like to discuss
And if the judge starts asking
something with Ms. Fitzharris, just let us know; happy to accommodate that.
is also on this call, there might be times when both of
us ask questions at the same time, especially given the remote nature.
happens, you know, just say you couldn't hear it, couldn't understand it, we'll stop, and I
So we're going to jump into just a little bit of background to get started,
And where do you currently live?
How long have you lived there?
Well, I do union construction and I have an epoxy floor business.
What do you do for a living?
Do you have any other jobs from construction or is it just working on
So leading up to January 6th just in general, and just to
give you a sense of, like, where we are in time, I'm thinking 2016, so like Trump's election
up until right before the November 2020 election.
question but, like, how politically engaged were you during that time?
I was engaged, not at first really.
And this is sort of an open-ended
I mean, I was engaged the whole time
And it seemed like all the same people on Facebook were
engaged in the same thing around the same time.
So were you paying, like, close attention to politics, do you think?
I didn't really care that much.
know what made me care that much, really.
I did go to hear him speak at Macomb Community College in Michigan [inaudible].
that was the first I went.
basically, is where I got it.
I didn't go to any other rallies.
But there was something about President Trump that made you
want to be -- to follow politics or to pay more attention?
Well, he said the right stuff.
You know, he was going to shape up
the government, help middle-class Americans, you know.
Make America Great, and we bought into it.
Basically, make it like he said,
Do you remember -- so you just mentioned Facebook.
getting most of your political news at the time or other --
coming through my Facebook feeds, I would say.
I mean, I would get it from Facebook and then look stuff up on
I wouldn't just go off Facebook.
But main source of it was
Was it friends posting or like organizations, like
CNN would post something on Facebook and put it there?
I wasn't really in any groups on Facebook, just -- yeah, just my news feed,
Basically, now that I look back at it, it was just -- I was getting one-sided
feeds the whole time, you know.
And these questions are really just to get a sense of like, you know, how
Were you watching, like, television news at all during that
people were consuming news at the time.
So it's -- and not necessarily specific to you,
It is specific to you, but I don't want you to think like -- we ask these of
So I'm going to go through like a list of social media applications.
of let me know if you use them for news.
I might have set up an account but never used it.
So I think when that started getting out, I was done with social
Ever heard of something called GETTR, G-E-T-T-R?
And then in terms of like print, did you ever, like, read newspapers, like print
Did you see, like, The Wall Street Journal a lot, New York Times?
How about like local newspapers, did that come across your Facebook feed?
The Detroit News would come across and the Macomb Daily would come
Do you really, like, remember his messaging a lot, like paying attention to it
Did you follow President Trump on Facebook?
So then, I guess, right around -- or right after, I should say, the
November 2020 election, did you believe that the election was stolen from President
And so what made you believe that?
Well, going back to that night, I was actually watching news channels and
And then, you know, go to bed and there is a huge lead, and
then wake up and it's gone.
at the same time, water main breaks, postal deliveries all around the same time.
just put stuff out there, make it -- I don't know if it's true or not, but it made it very
convincible that the election was stolen.
And all these coincidence happened at all these main cities
So do you remember where you were hearing those things?
Outsource -- different people's putting different stuff out there.
couldn't tell you specifically where I heard from this.
So let me try to -- you were paying attention on -- you were watching it on
the news, and you were watching it on Facebook --
-- and people were talking about these things?
Was former President Trump talking about these issues too, and
were you paying attention to those?
So is it fair to say that you almost right away, I guess, like when you woke up
the next morning, that you believed that the election was stolen?
I felt like, you know, just from what was out before the election, that
And how did you feel about that?
everyone kind of knew it was going to get tampered with.
then I question, well, why wouldn't something be done about it?
thought it was stolen when I woke up the next morning, basically.
And then how it went down, I felt like it was stolen.
Do you remember seeing posts about the possibility of the
And was that like a big topic on Facebook?
Not only Face book, but I go all over the country and work, and I work in a
union industry, you know, where you're supposed to vote Democratic -- Democrat --
You are supposed to vote how you feel.
And, you know, so I'm working with hard core
union members that all thought the same thing all over the country everywhere I went.
So it wasn't just me on my Face book; it was people I'd meet out in the real world too.
So having conversations with people who also had heard these
things, also had concerns about the elections, reinforced your views?
Did you ever have conversations with them about what they were listening
Well, basically, some of the sites you mentioned, Telegram,
you know, Facebook, Twitter, you know.
My one buddy gets all of his information from
You know, it just depends on what platform they prefer to use, I guess.
And did you get the sense that -- sorry.
In the time before the election
when you were talking to your friends or your colleagues, did you get the sense that they
were hearing this from President Trump, through social media, or from somewhere else?
Probably President Trump and some other places too.
So I'll jump back to after the election now.
So after the election, did you
participate in any activities related to election fraud following the election?
Did you make any political donations to groups that were arguing about election
fraud or election integrity between the election and January 6th?
Well, let's talk about -- we'll get to January 6th basically.
Well, President asked us to come.
And I had just worked from before
Thanksgiving till right before Christmas in Alabama every single day.
making a little trip out of it.
I thought it would be a good time.
Basically, he asked for us to come to D.C.
I planned on, like, going and seeing the city and everything,
So you mentioned that the President asked you.
Big things are going to happen.
And like I said, I planned on making a little trip out of
Do you remember a tweet from like December 19th where he asked
people to come and said it would be a wild protest?
I don't remember it in that words, but asking people to come, that there'd
You know, you don't want to miss it,
Do you remember like what date you decided to go to D.C.?
Well, we didn't actually even -- even the day we were supposed to go,
I didn't talk to Bobby till later on in the morning.
So I didn't even know the day we were
going to go if we were still going or not.
Christmas I started asking buddies if they wanted to go.
But it was a couple of days probably before
Did you have a lot of friends who were going to go, besides Mr. Schornack?
Well, we had our buddy Cliff who was the Tennessee sheriff, I knew he was
going, and we met him there.
But I had -- my two best friends, they backed out at the
last minute, so that's why I went to Bobby.
Did your best friends give you a reason why they backed out?
I just -- like I said, I had just worked.
time off and spending money in my pocket, so --
And did you drive up with him or with him and Cliff or just with him?
I picked Bobby up from his house and drove us to D.C.
Do you remember what date that was?
Is that Bobby Schornack, just for the record?
Me and Bobby drove to D.C. and met Cliff there.
So in between the time that you decided to go and the time that you
left, so let's say like late December, January 5th, were you paying attention to social
media to learn about what would happen on January 6th?
Was watching it and they said it's probably going to be hard
to get into D.C. with all the people.
And places to stay would be
limited, and -- but, you know, people just kept promising big things.
Trump, but other people on social media.
Do you remember any of those -- who those people were?
Were they, you know, elected officials or were they just kind of people you
like someone in Trump's camp or something like that would tweet something that would
make its way to Facebook, and --
Do you remember any specific, like, groups or organizations that were giving
There was a Stop the Steal group on Facebook, I think.
There was a few groups like that that just would come across my news feed even though I
So you were just sort of following what's going on and you had a
Did you ever, like, post about January 6th and say, hey, we should all go, try to get
other people besides your close group of friends to go?
I don't -- I don't think I posted anything just out there for the world, like, hey,
And then, basically, I said, Bobby, let's go.
I think I just said, hey, let's -- to my buddies, let's go.
And communicated with them the next few days.
So they said, no, can't go.
On Face book or whatever, did you hear talk about buses,
We -- what I heard is they were going to bus in
And that was another thing we were seeing before,
that the counter-protesters are going to be attacking Trump supporters and people that
went for the rally, and -- so, I mean, people -- like, the friends that didn't go, they were
worried a little bit, wanted to make sure I was safe and protected.
So you were worried about violence?
Was there any reason besides these posts about the floods of
counter-protesters that you were worried about violence?
Well, I mean, anytime you got that many people coming together, I mean,
there's always a worry of something happening, a bomb, whatever.
You know, you see snipers on the buildings and stuff, and scaffolding down by the Capitol,
and turn around there's people everywhere.
But, yeah, I was a little nervous going.
I was a little nervous being there even.
And so, I mean -- it was -- it wasn't like the
I mean, I was -- I enjoyed it, but I was nervous the whole time
So is it the -- back to the counter-protesters, what about them were you
Well, we'd see stuff like them attacking at other cities in marches or parades
They -- I mean, they would come across on news feed and you'd
see old people with bloody noses and they would blame it on antifa or something.
made it really seem like there was a good possibility that, like, be attacked by
Was antifa like a big topic on Facebook as well --
So was that something that you'd see a lot of videos and you were -- you felt
was a threat to the country?
-- a can of bear spray, a bulletproof vest, goggles.
Do you two want a second?
And is that why you -- did you bring anything with you to prepare
Can you give us a few seconds?
We'll go off the record for a second, at 2:24 p.m.
I just asked how did you prepare.
So it was bear spray, bulletproof vest -I'm sorry.
I just want to make sure we're on the record.
spray, but I did not bring those.
State of D.C. -- or the District of D.C.
I made sure everything I bought was legal to have in the
I did buy knives along with the bear
I might have gloves, and first aid kit, water.
And just -- I'm going to back up a little bit in thinking about the
Was there a lot of activity in Michigan about antifa or other protests
I mean, there was a kind of storming of the
Michigan capitol, I guess it would be, but was it illegal?
because who knows what's real out there anymore.
I guess they were allowed to be
But that's the only kind of thing I seen in Michigan was what
Like Oregon, I think there was a march in D.C. where it
I know someone was stabbed in Oregon.
I mean, I really don't know,
So in terms of Michigan, you mentioned the storming of the capitol.
it from your answer you weren't there?
I mean, there -- everyone knows the Michigan militia, I mean.
Did you know anybody who went?
Do you know any, like, militia groups in Michigan?
don't know anyone in it or involved in it, but everybody knows about them.
When you said everyone knows, you meant just like in general
We'll head back to Washington, D.C. in the next
Do you remember where you stayed in the area?
It was probably 15 minutes from the Memorial.
look at my credit card statement and find out the hotel.
I don't -- I mean, I could
It was a decent, nice hotel.
We didn't even have a reservation, that's how planned we were.
showed up and luckily got a room.
And that was in the District?
So I think you mentioned a knife.
bringing that to the hotel or did you leave that at home?
No, I left it at home in Michigan.
It might have been actually January 6th by the time we arrived.
So what time did you arrive January 5th?
midnight on to somewhere around there.
And you didn't see any activities that had happened on January 5th then?
So what time did you end up going to the Ellipse for the rally
Were you there just to hear President Trump speak or were you excited to
Well, I was excited because I was told, you know, we're going to tell you guys
this, tell you guys that, you know, big unveiling, unveiling.
I was -- after he spoke, I was -- it was just the same thing he's been saying.
nothing new, so -- so, yeah, I was kind of disappointed in the speech actually.
So you were -- you went hoping to hear some -- were you hoping to
And you -One at a time, please.
But, no, I mean, to be honest,
So let me reask the question.
Were you expecting to hear evidence about
the election being stolen from President Trump?
And were you -- when you listened to the speech, did you hear anything
Can you tell me like what the mood in the crowd was at that time?
I mean, patriotic I guess you'd call it.
they were yelling "fuck Trump" in the background.
get people to sign all this stuff.
Sorry for my language, but that's
And then there were these like Chinese nationals there trying to
Then I seen a couple of Oath Keepers.
Did you engage with the Oath Keepers or anybody?
I just stuck with basically Bobby, Cliff, and Cliff's friend that he
I mean, some -- I don't know, it was a
There was some people that looked like they were -- that sounded like
Basically stayed in the same area the whole time.
Did you talk to anybody else about your disappointment in President
Trump's speech while it was happening?
He might have said it's up to Pence to stop it --
What did you take President Trump to mean by that?
That basically Pence was his last chance probably to turn the election over.
So when you went to this rally, were you hoping that it would help President
Well, I don't know if that was the hope.
It also sounds like you wanted to hear some more information
So my direct question then would be, why were you at the rally?
To hear President Trump unveil some information that I hadn't heard before
And did you expect anything to happen after that reveal?
Well, there's all types of stuff that was out on the internet.
people thought that they were going to have a military tribune out in front there.
you know, I didn't know what the scaffolding was there for.
like I said, I wanted to have fun.
Do you recall President Trump saying anything about Vice President
I'm pretty sure I talked to Bobby about it; like, this is the same
speech we've been listening to the last 2 months, 3 months, you know.
And then there was all types of different theories that were out
Did January 6th, the date, mean anything specific to you when you went?
I was aware of that, yes.
And did you think that President Trump's reveal would in some way stop
So were you aware that Congress was certifying the electoral count
I didn't know if it would stop it or show proof that they should stop it.
that's what I was -- I thought there was going to be some type of proof, evidence that it
was going to get put in there and things that happens, which --
So did you hope that, with the evidence, maybe Vice President Pence would
Well, I was hoping it'd get stopped.
I didn't know really who would
I didn't know exact -- I don't know exactly how it goes.
And was that like a message going on in the crowd, you know, like, we're
here to stop the certification or --
Well, we were there to make our voices heard.
Were people in the crowd sharing
your hope that there would be something that stopped the certification?
Do you remember -- did you listen to President Trump's whole
speech or did you leave early?
I -- we listened to the whole speech.
We started looking for a bathroom
and heading, like, maybe couple minutes before he was finally done, but we still listened
Did you hear him say, you know, like, we're going to be marching to the
Capitol and I'll be with you --
Had you intended to go to the Capitol before you heard him say that?
I -- like I said, I didn't really have a plan.
So if you went with the day, when did you decide to go to the Capitol?
Well, I -- when everyone else started heading down there, after Trump was
as we were looking for a bathroom.
I just went with the day.
We looked for a bathroom and started walking down Congress that way
Why -- can I ask what then -- were you dressed in the sort of -- I don't know
But you didn't go back to the hotel first?
how best to describe it without the picture, but the helmet and the vest.
I just had a baseball hat on.
I had the vest on all day underneath my coat.
Were you expecting, when you were following everyone to the Capitol, that
And the vest was the bulletproof vest that you mentioned?
you would need to use those or need to use those for protection in some way?
I was worried that I'd have to.
There was a lot of people walking.
started to see snipers, you see this big crowd, you don't know.
So I had a hoping not to use it, need it.
And while you're walking, are you checking social media, like
The phones kind of stopped working.
You know, like being at a big sporting event or something, they just didn't work.
worked when they wanted to or when you could get through.
What was going on in the crowd as they were marching?
the same as at the rally or had things changed?
I mean, you had your louder groups of people as you're
building, they were yelling at them or chanting at them.
Nothing that I would think would escalate real quickly with the area I was walking down.
I think some stopped in front of the FBI building maybe, I don't know, some
So, yeah, I just walked down
There was people chanting, people with flags, people with banners.
Did you hear anybody saying things, like, hang Mike Pence?
I did hear that when I got, like, by the Capitol.
And as you're walking up to the Capitol, what do you see?
I'm seeing it's getting more crowded.
quick -Like I said, I walked down Congress.
I finally met people from Michigan.
through the crowd antagonizing, saying, Pence screwed you.
then I watched these kids go through and saying that to crowds as I'm walking up.
then me and Bobby got separated, and that's when we got like to the Capitol steps, and
We just talked to people like, you know, normal,
And we get there, and there was -- there was these kids that were going
I don't know what they were throwing it at,
because I couldn't see the top of the steps from where I was.
separated, so I was kind of looking around for Bobby.
I didn't see one cop from my walk from Congress, besides like on the side of
All the way up walking to the Capitol doors I didn't see one cop.
Did you see any tear gas, any fences down, any --
I heard -- I heard tear gas.
or fences, unless they were moved somewhere else by the time I got there.
very easy for me to walk up to the Capitol.
So while you're doing this, is there a reason that you were walking up to the
Well, we were trying to get close.
We went there, as you know, like I said,
to make our voices heard, be loud and all.
And then I got separated from Bobby, and
looked for Bobby basically at the foot of the steps for a while, and then walked up the
And what was going on while you were at the door of the Capitol?
Well, I was video recording, so I was just watching people walk in.
I mean, he had a red hat on, I kept thinking I'd see him, so I walked this way,
And then I was at the door of the Capitol.
recorded the windows were broke, but the doors were wide open.
walking right in like -- I don't know.
stopping them, telling them not to come in or anything.
happened right before I got to that point or -- I didn't see a police officer till I walked in,
turned right, and almost till I got to the Crypt is when I seen my first police officer.
Do you remember what time you walked in?
I don't know if that all
So it was pretty soon after the first people got in.
you that the first people got in around like 2:15 on the Senate side.
But were you seeing people pushing cops or barriers at all on your way up?
Did you see the first people get in?
There were people throwing stuff, like I said.
But I didn't see any cops blocking people.
But I couldn't see on the top.
the -- there was this little hill, I looked out for Bobby, then I went by the steps and started
making my way up the steps looking for him.
I couldn't see up there from where I was, so -- I went over on
of the steps, making different ways up the steps.
Was there anyone that you noticed encouraging people to go into the
Yeah, there was chants of "push forward"
But this was before I got to the Capitol.
This is the big crowd at the bottom
So if you're hearing "push forward" and people encouraging, did
you get the sense that there was something that was trying to stop all these people from
Well, I guess, but it's -- it's -- I didn't know if they were pushing each
other forward, but people were getting to the top and just walking.
walk by the wall up top; I just couldn't see the top of the stairs.
how close you could get to it really.
I was looking for Bobby and, I don't know, it was
kind of like a car crash, you want to see it but you don't want to get in it.
So you did -- at the time, you thought it was kind of like a car crash, or is this
Well, I'm thinking I want to get as close as I can, I want to
And I've got to find Bobby and this is the way Bobby was headed,
so that is the way I headed.
And like I said, I didn't have a problem with the crowd.
There was a group of -- like a line of people, just walked up
the steps, turned left, and when we got there, it opens up.
opened my backpack up, put my coat in there, took some video, and then went by the
door and seen the glass broken, took video, looked in, and then I walked in.
my mistake right there is walking in.
What did you think when you saw the broken glass?
I have video of like me, when I'm in there,
saying don't break anything, you know.
So why did you go in?
It was kind of disappointing to see that.
Why did you go in then?
I wasn't there to trash a building and
I wanted to find Bobby, and then the curiosity, so -- if one person would
have said get out of here, I would have turned around and left.
At that point, did you think going into the Capitol was part of making your
voice heard about your concerns with the election?
And did you get a sense of what other people were feeling at the time?
At that point, it was more find Bobby and get out of there.
There was some people that were aggressive and some people that,
you know, just probably wandered in there.
Some people wanted to be in there and
some people probably just wandered in there with the crowds and no one stopped them.
How can you tell some people wanted to be in there?
Because they were waving their flags around, putting -- you know, looking
I stayed along one wall and came back out the same way.
know, there was people that wanted something to happen, you could tell for sure.
then there's people that were just taking pictures and roaming around.
I was just on the outskirts basically the whole time.
And did you get a sense of what they wanted to happen?
The sense was they wanted to stop whatever was happening there, which,
you know -- I can't speak for them.
I don't know what they wanted, but my sense is they
wanted to do something about what was going on.
And was that reflected in what they were chanting?
Besides I heard the "hang Pence" probably in there once or twice.
then, you know, maybe like "find Nancy" or something like that.
it was just chanting USA, USA, and --
Would you still say at that time that the mood felt patriotic?
Not to me, but, I mean -- yeah, I would say people thought they were being
Then when did you end up finding him?
I ended up sneaking into one side, and then I turned around and took my
So did you find Bobby inside?
Went back out on to Congress and my phone started
And I got a hold of Cliff, met up with Cliff.
hotel -- took an Uber back to the hotel.
by that time, Bobby was able to get a hold of us and we picked him up at the Memorial.
Got the car, came back to the Memorial.
Did you take any pictures while you were inside?
So I think, and you can correct me if I'm wrong, but I was looking at your
statement of facts that was filed with your case in the docket, and there might be a selfie
that you took in there with a friend in the Capitol.
I believe that was Mr. Schornack.
but I just wanted to confirm for the record.
I got to the end of it.
So can you -- you left the Capitol.
Was there any specific reason that you
I was a firefighter, so I stayed along the walls
followed the wall back with my left hand and out.
didn't want to -- there was too many people.
to go through the whole place looking for him.
they were trying to get the doors shut so no more people would come in.
And I wasn't going any deeper.
And I didn't find Bobby, and I wasn't going
So I turn around, I left on my own
And the police, they made me climb out through a window, because I think
Do you have any sense of how long you were in there?
These next questions might be easier for Ms. Fitzharris to answer, if you'd like.
It's just, what's the current status of the case?
His sentencing hearing is scheduled for April 1st.
Mr. Herendeen pleaded guilty with a plea agreement to a class A
We're just going to close out with a few questions about, you know, sort of
So how you felt since then.
what do you think about January 6th, the day itself, now?
Like, looking back on the day,
I think it's a black mark on history.
I -- like I said, that -- something was going on in the tunnel, there was
fighting with the Capitol Police, that is just pure ridiculousness.
After that, I got off social media.
It just -- it messed up my life and it wasn't worth it.
Is it -- do you feel at all betrayed by the politics?
I would -- I feel a little betrayed, a little abandoned, a little
